Keywords: quantum network simulator, quantum internet, quantum network architecture, network protocol design
Abstract

line_1.text: Recent advances in quantum information science enabled the development of quantum

line_2.text: communication network prototypes and created an opportunity to study full-stack quantum

line_3.text: network architectures. This work develops SeQUeNCe, a comprehensive, customizable quantum

line_4.text: network simulator. Our simulator consists of ﬁve modules: hardware models, entanglement

line_5.text: management protocols, resource management, network management, and application. This

line_6.text: framework is suitable for simulation of quantum network prototypes that capture the breadth of

line_7.text: current and future hardware technologies and protocols. We implement a comprehensive suite of

line_8.text: network protocols and demonstrate the use of SeQUeNCe by simulating a photonic quantum

line_9.text: network with nine routers equipped with quantum memories. The simulation capabilities are

line_10.text: illustrated in three use cases. We show the dependence of quantum network throughput on several

line_11.text: key hardware parameters and study the impact of classical control message latency. We also

line_12.text: investigate quantum memory usage efﬁciency in routers and demonstrate that redistributing

line_13.text: memory according to anticipated load increases network capacity by 69.1% and throughput by

line_14.text: 6.8%. We design SeQUeNCe to enable comparisons of alternative quantum network technologies,

line_15.text: experiment planning, and validation and to aid with new protocol design. We are releasing

line_16.text: SeQUeNCe as an open source tool and aim to generate community interest in extending it.

line_0.text: 1. Introduction
Quantum networks promise to deliver new, revolutionary applications that include distributing

line_1.text: cryptographic keys with provable security [6, 28], solving distributed computational tasks with exponential

line_2.text: reduction in communication complexity [13], or synchronizing clocks with unprecedented accuracy [34] to

line_3.text: name just a few. Recent breakthroughs in quantum engineering have allowed experimental realizations of

line_4.text: quantum network prototypes [31, 67] that are supplemented by commercial efforts in the network security

line_5.text: arena [64].

line_0.text: Prototypes of metropolitan quantum networks with multiple nodes are currently under construction

line_1.text: e.g. in Chicago [65], the Netherlands [15], the United Kingdom [26], and South Korea [69]. One of the

line_2.text: most signiﬁcant engineering challenge is building networks that scale both in the number of users and

line_3.text: communication distance. Achieving this goal requires a combination of advances in hardware engineering,

line_4.text: standardization of new network architectures, development of robust control plane protocols, and

line_5.text: techniques that allow reproducible performance testing.

line_0.text: Quantum network simulations can help in understanding the tradeoffs of alternative quantum network
architectures, optimizing quantum hardware, and developing a robust control plane. As the size of

line_1.text: experimental networks grows and new protocols and technologies are developed, the need to use

simulations to model the behavior and interactions of these complex systems increases. The classical

line_1.text: networking community has been relying on network simulators to achieve similar goals, with simulators

line_2.text: such as ns-3 [57] receiving widespread use in academia and industry alike.

line_0.text: This work builds a Simulator of QUantum Network Communication (SeQUeNCe), a customizable

line_1.text: discrete-event quantum network simulator that models quantum hardware and network protocols. Since

line_2.text: the community has not yet agreed on the architecture of the quantum internet, we do not impose a rigid

line_3.text: layering structure [77]. Instead we introduce a modularized design of the simulator that separates

line_4.text: functionality at different network layers into modules. This modularized design allows the testing of

line_5.text: alternative quantum network protocols and hardware models and the study of their interactions. Our

line_6.text: simulator design also allows easy customizability. SeQUeNCe is freely available as open source on GitHub

line_7.text: [55], allowing users to test the performance of new algorithms, protocols, and devices by implementing new

line_8.text: functionality in Python and running one of our built-in benchmarks.

line_0.text: Simulating quantum networks is challenging for four reasons. First, although recent work has provided
important insights about future quantum network architectures [68, 71], the lack of consensus about

line_1.text: architectural principles requires abstracting certain details and considering many alternatives. We address

line_2.text: this challenge by using a modularized design that allows intermodule communication. Second, quantum

line_3.text: network protocols are typically described as algorithms [3, 8], and signiﬁcant effort is needed to map each

line_4.text: of these algorithms to the correct network layer and deﬁne its behavior and interactions with other

line_5.text: protocols. Our initial work translates a comprehensive suite of quantum network protocols into state

line_6.text: machines that capture all possible protocol states and interactions of the protocols. The third set of

line_7.text: challenges comes from the fundamental differences between quantum and classical networks. For example,

line_8.text: while classical networks use packets, quantum networks carry information inside photons generated at

line_9.text: megahertz frequencies [14]. The last challenge is scalability of the simulator. Simulations of networks of

line_10.text: increasing sizes and the need to maintain and manipulate multi-qubit quantum states require new methods

line_11.text: to improve scalability. Parallelization of the simulator for use on supercomputers is planned for future

line_0.text: Our earlier work introduced models of QKD protocols and evaluated their performance [72]. These

line_1.text: models are now part of the SeQUeNCe simulator. Our earlier work also modeled quantum teleportation

line_2.text: experiments [73]. Comparisons with experiments allowed us to demonstrate the accuracy of our simulation

line_3.text: techniques. The present work introduces the SeQUeNCe simulator, explains its design and functionality,

line_4.text: and showcases its use for simulation of a local area quantum repeater network. We designed SeQUeNCe to

line_5.text: track millions of events per second of simulation time, and the most intensive simulations reported in this

line_6.text: paper generate approximately two billion events.

line_0.text: Development of quantum network simulators that capture the complexity of full-stack quantum
networks started receiving signiﬁcant attention in the past two years. In addition to SeQUeNCe, two other

line_1.text: concurrently developed simulators, NetSquid [17, 20] and QuISP [40], were introduced as software

line_2.text: packages in mid-2020. Because all three simulators have different internal structure and differ in key

line_3.text: assumptions and implementation details, we strongly believe that comparing the work of the three teams

line_4.text: will lead to an exchange of ideas and better understanding of quantum networks. We compare the three

line_5.text: simulators in section 6.

line_0.text: The main contributions of this work are fourfold:

line_1.text: • Design and implementation of a scalable, customizable, discrete-event quantum network simulator,

line_0.text: SeQUeNCe, that models the behavior of quantum networks with picosecond precision
• Release of the simulator as an open source tool freely available on GitHub [55]

line_1.text: • Description of a modularized quantum network architecture, including detailed descriptions, models,

line_0.text: and implementations of key protocols in each module
• Three representative use cases that demonstrate the functionality of the simulator by modeling a
metropolitan quantum network under construction in Chicago
The paper is organized as follows. In section 2 we introduce basic terminology, explain how quantum
networks operate, and highlight some of their most prominent features. In section 3 we introduce

line_1.text: simulation requirements and the design of the SeQUeNCe simulator that consists of ﬁve elementary

line_2.text: modules and a simulation kernel. Section 4 describes models and presents detailed descriptions of quantum

line_3.text: network hardware and control protocols. Simulation results obtained with the SeQUeNCe simulator are

line_4.text: presented in section 5, and related work is discussed in section 6.

2. Background
In recent years, much work has gone into the development of hardware that enables quantum networks

line_1.text: [62], understanding potential network architectures [35], and ﬁnding new applications [71]. However,

line_2.text: architectural principles and the associated control protocols remain nascent, and signiﬁcant advances in

line_3.text: both traditional networking disciplines and quantum engineering are needed to realize a full-stack quantum

line_4.text: internet.

line_0.text: We begin by introducing the basic concepts in quantum communication. Quantum networks transmit

line_1.text: information encoded in quantum states, mathematical constructs that yield a probability distribution for

line_2.text: the measurement outcomes on a quantum system. For an isolated two-level atom, a quantum state is a

line_3.text: complex vector denoting a superposition of the atom in the two energy levels. Such a quantum state can be

line_4.text: used to encode quantum information—a qubit—with the two levels representing a ‘0’ (i.e. |0(cid:3)) or ‘1’ (|1(cid:3)).

line_5.text: Quantum states are operated on by quantum gates. They act on a qubit or multiple qubits and change

line_6.text: their quantum state. Quantum gates perform reversible logical operations on qubits, in contrast to classical

line_7.text: gates that can be irreversible. An example of a quantum gate is the controlled NOT (CNOT) gate [47],

line_8.text: which takes two qubits as input and ﬂips the second qubit (the target qubit) if and only if the ﬁrst qubit (the

line_0.text: Applying CNOT gates on independent qubits can create entanglement, a multipartite (2 or more
particles) quantum state that cannot be expressed as a product of states of individual particles [27]. In other

line_1.text: words, when entangled, each particle’s state is not independent of the others. A well-known example is a

line_2.text: Bell state [47]: 1/

line_3.text: mechanics. It can exist among particles even though they are physically separated in space [27].

line_0.text: 2(|01(cid:3) + |10(cid:3)). Entanglement is a fundamentally unique property of quantum
Entanglement can be used for quantum teleportation, a process to transfer an arbitrary quantum state

line_1.text: (and the qubit information it encodes) from a sender to a distant receiver [7]. In order to teleport quantum

line_2.text: information, a high-ﬁdelity entanglement shared between the two parties must be ﬁrst established; the

line_3.text: sender then entangles the state it wishes to teleport with one qubit of the entangled pair and measures these

line_4.text: two qubits. Finally, classical communication is used to send these measurement results to the receiver who

line_5.text: uses them to correct the Pauli frame of the receiver’s qubit to obtain the teleported state.

line_0.text: Noise and loss can harm the high-ﬁdelity entanglement required for teleportation [8]. Thus one must

line_1.text: perform entanglement puriﬁcation (or distillation), a process that transforms many copies of entangled

line_2.text: states (typically of a lesser degree of entanglement) into fewer copies of higher ﬁdelity entangled states,

line_3.text: using local quantum gates and classical communication [5, 8].

line_0.text: Global efforts have been undertaken to physically realize quantum networks. These efforts typically

line_1.text: resort to technological platforms based on either ground-based ﬁber-optic networks [19, 31, 49, 60, 64, 67]

line_2.text: or satellite links [75]. The ﬁrst method can be naturally realized through the use of existing global

line_3.text: telecommunication ﬁber-optic infrastructure. These ﬁbers, while having minimal attenuation at the telecom

line_4.text: band, still suffer from transmission loss of approximately 0.2 dB km−1 [18]. To date, point-to-point

line_5.text: photonic ﬁber links for quantum key distribution have been experimentally realized, with many

line_6.text: metropolitan networks already deployed or currently under construction [25, 49, 60, 67]. Transmitting

line_7.text: quantum information beyond metropolitan distances, however, would require placing quantum repeater

line_8.text: nodes at intervals of a few tens to a 100 kilometers. These nodes work to counteract photon loss and

line_9.text: operation errors in the network, and thus improve the achievable communication distance and rate [46].

line_10.text: Physical realization of a functional quantum repeater is a subject of active research [51], and several

line_11.text: alternative designs that differ in engineering difﬁculty have been proposed [46]. For the time being,

line_12.text: developing a fully-functional quantum repeater node remains a major engineering challenge.

line_0.text: The second way to realize a long-distance quantum internet relies on ground-satellite links, which can
connect distant nodes of 1000 km separation with a single satellite station. Nevertheless, satellite-based

line_1.text: quantum networks have obvious shortcomings, including weather restrictions, intermittent operations, and

line_2.text: low throughput. In this paper, we thus focus on simulation of a ﬁber-based quantum network. However,

line_3.text: our simulator can be extended for satellite-based quantum networks as well through the substitution of

line_4.text: models for network edges and entanglement protocols with minimal change to other simulator modules.

line_5.text: The unique properties of quantum physics result in three fundamental differences between quantum

line_0.text: and classical networks. First, the no-cloning theorem prevents copying quantum information without

line_1.text: destroying the original [36]. Unlike in a classical network, one therefore cannot use an ampliﬁer to

line_2.text: regenerate signals on long-distance links. Combined with the unavoidable loss during transmission, directly

line_3.text: transmitting quantum information in a scalable quantum network is almost impossible [2].

line_0.text: The second difference is reliance on quantum entanglement, which does not exist for classical networks.
To provide reliable information transmission, quantum networks use entanglement to teleport quantum

line_1.text: states or rely on quantum error correction. Although entanglement can be established among qubits,

line_0.text: Quantum Sci. Technol. 6 (2021) 045027
X Wu et al
classical users cannot directly observe such states from qubits. Only heralded signals (conveyed as classical

line_1.text: information) can determine the current quantum state. The usage of entanglement then relies on both

line_2.text: classical and quantum information.

line_0.text: The third fundamental difference is the time sensitivity of quantum networks. Many operations, such as

line_1.text: Bell state measurement (BSM), require synchronous operations over long distances. Furthermore, quantum

line_2.text: information that decoheres over time cannot be easily refreshed as classical information. The lifetime of

line_3.text: quantum information simulated in this work is usually on the order of milliseconds to seconds [1, 53].

line_0.text: 3. System design
The differences between quantum and classical networks call for a ﬂexible and scalable quantum network

line_1.text: simulator that allows accurate performance analysis of network architectures. We explore its design in this

line_2.text: section.

line_0.text: 3.1. Quantum network simulation requirements

line_1.text: We desire the following simulator characteristics:

line_0.text: Realism of quantum states: the simulator must be able to accurately trace quantum states, such as
entanglement, as well as their ﬁdelity. Furthermore, states can be encoded as time bins [38], in the

line_1.text: polarization of light [12], or as states in quantum memories [44]. The quality of entanglement is a key

line_2.text: quantum network performance metric, and loss and decoherence that affect it must be modeled. In

line_3.text: SeQUeNCe, we provide Bra–Ket [61] and density matrix [29] representations of quantum states. The

line_4.text: hardware models record entanglement ﬁdelity.

line_0.text: Realism of timing: simulation events must be precisely executed at their respective timestamps with

line_1.text: their exact ordering to avoid causality errors. Quantum networks are time-sensitive systems, and the arrival

line_2.text: times of photons that encode quantum information determine their identity. In addition, the lifetime of

line_3.text: qubits in memories is limited, requiring that certain operations be performed with as low latency as

line_4.text: possible. Our simulator operates with picosecond precision, which provides suitable granularity for current

line_5.text: and near-term technologies while allowing sufﬁciently long simulation time.

line_0.text: Flexibility: in order to support development of future quantum networks, the simulator must be able to
simulate alternative network architectures and new protocols and applications and allow reconﬁgurable

line_1.text: topologies and trafﬁc traces. To that end, SeQUeNCe uses a modularized design that separates functionality

line_2.text: into modules that contain protocols that can be reprogrammed. Quick testing of a large number of

line_3.text: scenarios is possible by changing parameters in JSON ﬁles.

line_0.text: Scalability: we must be able to perform large-scale studies of wide area networks with many

line_1.text: components, as well as track quantum states at the individual photon level. In contrast to classical

line_2.text: packet-level network simulations, we must track photons generated with megahertz frequencies, increasing

line_3.text: the number of simulated events by several orders of magnitude. Although this paper focuses on sequential

line_4.text: discrete event simulation, we started exploring efﬁcient parallel simulation methods [74] and designed a

line_5.text: stand-alone simulation kernel to allow portability to high-performance computing systems.

line_0.text: 3.2. Modularized design of SeQUeNCe

line_1.text: To simulate quantum networks, we have to make some assumptions about their architecture. However,

line_2.text: quantum network architectures have not been standardized yet, and this topic is the subject of many lively

line_3.text: discussions in the recently established Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) standardization group [43].

line_4.text: We carefully studied the often conﬂicting quantum network designs, including the seminal works of Van

line_5.text: Meter [68] and Wehner et al [71]. To allow simulation of alternative and emerging quantum network

line_6.text: architectures, we made minimal assumptions and identiﬁed the nascent architectural principles that are

line_7.text: common to most quantum network designs. This allowed us to introduce a simpliﬁed modularized

line_8.text: quantum network design with ﬁve modules that allow modeling many potential future network

line_9.text: architectures. SeQUeNCe adds a sixth module, the simulation kernel, to generate events. This design is

line_10.text: shown in ﬁgure 1. Next we describe the role and interactions of the modules.

line_0.text: Simulation kernel is the heart of SeQUeNCe and contains an event scheduler and a quantum manager.
The event scheduler enables discrete-event simulation. Simulation time advances in discrete jumps, and

line_1.text: events generated by the simulation models in all other modules are stored in a priority queue (i.e.

line_2.text: min-heap) sorted by the event timestamp. The event scheduler continuously executes the top event in the

line_3.text: heap and advances the simulation time to that particular timestamp. This procedure repeats until the

line_4.text: priority queue is empty or a simulation end condition is met. The event scheduler gives users extreme

line_5.text: control over the event execution orders for timing realism and provides interfaces for future parallelized

line_6.text: implementation for scalability enhancement. The quantum manager is responsible for tracking all quantum

Figure 1. Modularized design of SeQUeNCe closely matching an abstract quantum network architecture.
states during simulation. Quantum states are stored as key-value pairs, where the values are vectors

line_1.text: (Bra–ket notation [61]) or matrices (density matrix [29]) together with a list that indicates which states are

line_2.text: entangled. Objects that need to maintain and manipulate quantum states, such as quantum memories, use a

line_3.text: unique key to access the data structure representing the state. The quantum state can be changed using

line_4.text: provided interfaces. This design allows for convenient manipulation of multi-qubit states that may be

line_5.text: distributed between multiple objects across the network and guarantees consistency. For example,

line_6.text: measuring one of two qubits in the maximally entangled state |00(cid:3) + |11(cid:3) immediately impacts the state of

line_7.text: the other qubit that can be referenced by an object that holds the appropriate key.

line_0.text: Hardware module includes models of elementary hardware components used in a quantum network,

line_1.text: including quantum channels, classical channels, quantum gates, photon detectors, and quantum memories.

line_2.text: Each hardware model provides an interface to allow the application, entanglement, and network modules to

line_3.text: query and update its states. Our prior work evaluated the realism of the models of some of these

line_4.text: components and demonstrated their interactions [72, 73]. This work signiﬁcantly extends these models and

line_5.text: introduces new components, such as quantum memories necessary for long-distance quantum

line_6.text: communication. Note that in our implementation some of the hardware state is maintained by the resource

line_7.text: management module. This decision simpliﬁes the simulator design and does not require any direct

line_8.text: communication from the resource manager to the hardware module.

line_0.text: Entanglement management module includes models of protocols for reliable high-ﬁdelity end-to-end

line_1.text: distribution of entangled qubit pairs between network nodes. Speciﬁcally, this module includes protocols

line_2.text: for entanglement generation [3], entanglement puriﬁcation [8], and entanglement swapping [33]. The role

line_3.text: of entanglement generation is to create pairs of entangled qubits. Next, entanglement puriﬁcation is used to

line_4.text: improve the ﬁdelity of the entanglement. Entanglement swapping is used to transform multiple

line_5.text: shorter-distance entangled pairs into a single long-distance entangled pair. SeQUeNCe models these

line_6.text: protocols and tracks the quantum state, lifetime, and ﬁdelity of entanglement. This module is allowed to

line_7.text: change the quantum state of hardware and releases hardware resources upon protocol completion.

line_0.text: Resource management module manages local resources within one node. It records the state of the

line_1.text: hardware, efﬁciently allocates resources to applications and entanglement protocols based on commands

line_2.text: issued by the network management module, and regains control of the hardware with updated states when

line_3.text: resources are released. Although the resource manager controls only local resources, the instantiation of

line_4.text: entanglement protocols requires cooperation between resource managers on different nodes. This

line_5.text: cooperation ensures that entangled pairs are mapped to the correct quantum memories and entanglement

line_6.text: management protocol instances.

line_0.text: Network management module provides quantum network services based on requests from the local
applications and remote network managers. It communicates with the resource manager to check the

line_1.text: available local resources and generates commands for the resource manager to realize an appropriate

line_2.text: resource allocation scheme.

line_0.text: Application module represents quantum network applications and their requests for quantum network
resources. Although scientists envision a variety of disparate quantum network applications, including

line_1.text: precise clock synchronization, quantum teleportation, or highly secure cryptographic key distribution, all

line_2.text: these applications rely on entanglement. An application can initiate distribution of entanglement between

itself and another network node and specify the start time, duration, frequency, and ﬁdelity of the

line_1.text: entanglement distribution.

line_0.text: The SeQUeNCe simulator is highly reconﬁgurable. The user is allowed to specify the network topology
and a variety of network and protocol parameters in a JSON ﬁle. The JSON ﬁle automatically creates and

line_1.text: conﬁgures the appropriate simulation models. In addition, the modularized design was created for easy

line_2.text: extendability and allows advanced users to create their own models of new quantum hardware and network

line_3.text: protocols.

line_0.text: Here we show an example sequence of steps required to distribute entanglement between node-1 and

line_1.text: node-3 connected in a linear network topology as follows: node-1 → node-2 → node-3. After node-1 makes

line_2.text: a reservation, the network utilizes quantum memories to distribute entanglement. This example is

line_3.text: illustrated step-by-step with the step number corresponding to the labels in ﬁgure 1:

line_0.text: 1. The application on node-1 requests a service from its local network manager.

line_1.text: 2. The network manager invokes a routing protocol to identify a route and announces the request to the

line_2.text: network managers on that route, namely, in node-2 and node-3. For each node on the path, the

line_3.text: network manager veriﬁes the availability of memories with the local resource manager, and passes the

line_4.text: reservation to the next node in the path. If the request reaches the end of the path and is approved by

line_5.text: all nodes, the request is served and the approval passed back along the path (so that all nodes may serve

line_6.text: the request). The network manager notiﬁes the application of the approval or rejection of the request.

line_0.text: 3. The resource manager module on each node allocates memories for use by the local entanglement
manager.
4. The entanglement manager on each node utilizes the allocated memories to execute entanglement
generation, puriﬁcation, and swapping protocols. The respective protocol instances on participating

line_1.text: nodes communicate with each other to facilitate the desired entanglement operations. After completion

line_2.text: of all protocol instances, entanglement with the desired ﬁdelity is established between node-1 and

line_3.text: node-3.

line_0.text: 5. The resource manager on each node continuously tracks the state of local quantum memories and
allocates memories to the application when the desired entanglement (node-1 to node-3) is established.

line_1.text: The application then consumes the entanglement between node-1 and node-3.

line_0.text: 6. The application releases the quantum memory after use. At that point, the released memory can be
reused by the resource manager for current or future requests.
4. Design, implementation, and simulation of modules
This section describes the design and implementation of models that follow the modularized architecture

line_1.text: described in section 3. These models can be easily extended and support for additional hardware, protocols

line_2.text: and applications can be added to the simulator in the future. We describe models of the elementary

line_3.text: hardware building blocks of quantum networks in section 4.1. The entanglement management module is

line_4.text: discussed in section 4.2. We implemented the Barrett–Kok entanglement generation protocol [3] to

line_5.text: generate entanglement between adjacent nodes, the BBPSSW protocol [8] to purify entanglement, and a

line_6.text: swapping protocol [33] to extend the distance of entanglement. Our resource management module,

line_7.text: described in section 4.3, consists of a memory manager and a rule manager. We present the network

line_8.text: management module in section 4.4. It uses both a reservation and a routing protocol to create paths. In

line_9.text: section 4.5 we describe a simpliﬁed application module that mimics quantum network trafﬁc generated by

line_0.text: 4.1. Hardware

line_1.text: Here we describe how we model the key hardware elements in a quantum network. Our models of hardware

line_2.text: elements simulate the behavior of the physical system and track its state and operational parameters.

line_0.text: 4.1.1. Quantum and classical channels

line_1.text: Quantum channels in photonic networks use standard telecommunication ﬁber to transmit quantum

line_2.text: information. Our model of a quantum channel has two functions: schedule and transmit. The

line_3.text: schedule function is used to determine the earliest available transmission time for the transmit

line_4.text: function. The transmit function sends a photon to the other end of the channel. We model the

line_5.text: propagation delay as L/c∗, where L denotes the length of ﬁber and c∗ denotes the speed of light in the ﬁber.

line_6.text: We model the loss rate of the quantum channel as 10− L·αo

line_7.text: dB km−1. To avoid transmitting multiple photons at the same time over the same channel, the modeled

line_0.text: 10 , where αo is the attenuation measured in

quantum channel uses time-division multiplexing (TDM) and assigns a time of transmission to each

line_1.text: photon source. Our simulator synchronizes all photon sources sharing a channel in order to ensure proper

line_2.text: spacing of photons from different sources.

line_0.text: The classical channel is used to transmit classical information. Users can deﬁne the delay manually. For
simplicity, we assume no-loss and perfect reliability for the classical channel in the current version of the

line_1.text: simulator.

line_0.text: 4.1.2. Single photon detectors

line_1.text: A single-photon detector (SPD) is used to detect individual photon arrivals. An SPD generates an electrical

line_2.text: signal upon absorption of a photon and records its arrival time. The detector efﬁciency ηd is the probability

line_3.text: that a photon is successfully detected when it hits the detector. The detector resolution determines the

line_5.text: events. This ‘dead time’ is the inverse of the count rate. Another property of the SPD is the dark count rate,

line_7.text: noise. We model dark count events as a Poisson process. Within the simulation, detectors can be used in a

line_8.text: BSM device. This component receives photons, directs them to an SPD, and ensures the proper

line_9.text: entanglement of the photon sources. We evaluated the accuracy of the channel and detector models in our

line_0.text: 4.1.3. Quantum memories

line_1.text: As an essential component of quantum repeater, quantum memory is used to store quantum information in

line_2.text: the form of matter (or stationary) qubits. In this work, we model single-atom memories [63], where the

line_3.text: qubit is stored as the spin state of a single atom, atomic defect, or ion [10, 23, 63]. We simulate a quantum

line_4.text: network composed of multiple single-atom memories connected by ﬁber-optic channels.

line_0.text: The matter system of a quantum memory consists of two long-lived, low-lying states | ↑(cid:3) and | ↓(cid:3) and
one excited state |e(cid:3). The ‘excite’ operation induces the transformation | ↓(cid:3) → |e(cid:3) and | ↑(cid:3) → | ↑(cid:3). The

line_1.text: transition | ↑(cid:3) ↔ |e(cid:3) is not allowed in the physical system. Along with the transformation | ↓(cid:3) → |e(cid:3), one

line_2.text: photon entangled with the memory may be emitted.

line_0.text: The modeled quantum memory has two functions: excite and expire. The excite function
implements the excite operation described above and may cause the memory to emit a photon. The

line_1.text: probability of photon emission is decided by the quantum state and the efﬁciency of memory ηm. Given

line_3.text: quantum state α| ↓(cid:3) + β| ↑(cid:3) stored in a memory, the probability of emitting a photon is given by ηm

line_4.text: The quantum memory then needs time to relax its quantum state back to the ground state before the next

line_5.text: excite operation. This time of relaxation determines the frequency of the quantum memory. Entanglement is

line_6.text: generated by performing a BSM (described in section 4.1.2) on photons emitted by two quantum memories

line_7.text: in the excited state. The generated entanglement has a limited lifetime (the coherence time) that starts with

line_8.text: the excite operation and ends with a scheduled expire operation that resets the quantum state.

line_0.text: When entanglement is established between the states of two memories, both need to maintain additional
information such as the identity of the entangled quantum states. In our implementation, apart from the

line_1.text: quantum state, the quantum memory also maintains the ﬁdelity of entanglement, ranging from 0 (no

line_2.text: entanglement) to 1 (perfect entanglement), which is visible to entanglement management protocols.

line_3.text: We consider a repeater architecture based on single-atom memories (as deﬁned above), where the

line_0.text: ﬁdelity of entanglement is dependent on atom-cavity cooperativity—an experimental parameter

line_1.text: quantifying the coupling strength between an atom memory and a single photon. Based on [1], we have

line_3.text: atom’s optical decay rate, γ∗ denotes the optical pure dephasing rate, and Δω denotes the difference

line_4.text: between the optical transition frequencies of the two atomic memories to be entangled.

4.1.4. Nodes

line_1.text: We follow the outline from a recent IETF draft [37] and deﬁne two types of network nodes: router nodes

line_2.text: and BSM nodes. The router nodes implement the full-stack functionality described in this section in order to

line_3.text: reliably distribute entanglement in the network. Our router node has all the functionality of a quantum

line_4.text: repeater to overcome photon loss described in section 4.1.1. The router also allows routing in the traditional

line_5.text: sense. The second type of node is the BSM node that is required by the Barrett–Kok entanglement

line_6.text: generation protocol described in section 4.2. These nodes are placed in the middle of each link as shown in

line_7.text: ﬁgure 3.

line_0.text: 4.2. Entanglement management

line_1.text: The entanglement management module includes models of protocols for entanglement generation,

line_2.text: puriﬁcation, and swapping. We reference existing protocols and model their functional behavior, including

line_3.text: state machines and the exchange of classical messages. The entanglement management module provides an

line_4.text: interface for instantiating and terminating entanglement protocols, which the resource management

line_5.text: module utilizes to establish entanglement. It also provides interfaces to receive notiﬁcations of events such

line_6.text: as photon detection and entanglement expiration, used by the hardware module. Upon receiving an

line_7.text: entanglement expiration notiﬁcation, the corresponding protocol instances will release their resources and

line_8.text: terminate themselves.

4.2.1. Barrett–Kok entanglement generation protocol

line_1.text: The Barrett–Kok entanglement generation protocol [3] utilizes matter qubits and linear optics. Compared

line_2.text: with the DLCZ entanglement generation protocol [59], this protocol can tolerate the most signiﬁcant

line_3.text: hardware errors such as detector loss and spontaneous emission.

line_0.text: Figure 3 shows the setup of the Barrett–Kok entanglement generation protocol, where two quantum

line_1.text: memories are connected to a beam splitter (BS) by optical channels. The quantum memories are prepared

line_2.text: (|↑(cid:3) + |↓(cid:3)) state; the 50:50 BS is used to erase the photon source information; and the single

line_3.text: in the |+(cid:3) = 1√

line_5.text: photon detectors D+ and D− are used to detect emitted photons. Quantum nodes synchronize the times to

line_6.text: excite the memories, guaranteeing that the emitted photons from both sides arrive at the BS simultaneously.

line_7.text: The protocol involves two rounds. The ﬁrst round generates entanglement between two qubits, and the

line_0.text: second round improves the entangled state. The protocol produces a pair of entangled memories with

line_1.text: maximal entanglement state |Ψ+(cid:3) or |Ψ−(cid:3). We show a detailed description of this protocol, including the

line_2.text: state machine we have developed to allow its implementation, in appendix A.

line_0.text: 4.2.2. BBPSSW puriﬁcation protocol

line_1.text: Entanglement puriﬁcation protocols were developed to address entanglement imperfections caused by

line_2.text: factors including imperfections and decoherence in quantum memories. A puriﬁcation protocol [24]

line_3.text: consumes several pairs of entangled qubits with low quality F to produce a pair of entangled qubits with

line_4.text: high quality F(cid:11). Puriﬁcation requires the use of quantum gates.

line_0.text: In this work, we adapted and implemented the BBPSSW protocol [8] for puriﬁcation. The ﬁdelity

line_1.text: improvement is shown in equation (3) and the success probability in equation (4), where psuc denotes the

line_2.text: probability of success. For more details on the design and implementation of our BBPSSW protocol model,

line_3.text: see appendix B.

4.2.3. Swapping protocol

line_1.text: Entanglement swapping [33] is used in quantum networks to transform multiple short-distance

line_2.text: entanglements into a single long-distance entanglement. Figure 4 shows the entanglement state before and

line_3.text: after the swapping protocol. To illustrate the procedure, we consider three nodes A, B, and C arranged in a

line_4.text: linear topology. Initially, one memory at A and one at C are each entangled to memories at B. Entanglement

line_5.text: swapping involves application of a BSM at node B, after which the memories at node A and C are entangled

line_6.text: with each other. After this operation, B must send a message with the BSM result to allow Pauli frame

line_7.text: correction in nodes A and C to create the desired entangled state. Together with the message containing the

line_8.text: BSM result, we also transmit the updated ﬁdelity of entanglement, the updated identity of the entangled

line_9.text: memory (which memories are entangled on A and C), and the updated lifetime of entanglement. Note that

line_10.text: we choose the smaller value as the updated lifetime if two memories have different lifetimes.

line_0.text: The success probability and degradation of swapping Fd are deﬁned by the operations performed at the

line_1.text: intermediate node. The degradation comes from imperfect gate operations. Given two pairs of entangled

line_2.text: memory with ﬁdelity F1 and F2, the ﬁdelity F of new entanglement after swapping is [1]

line_0.text: F = F1F2Fd.
For details on the design and implementation of our entanglement swapping protocol model, see

4.3. Resource management

line_1.text: We design and implement a resource manager module to manage local resources. Similar to the design of

line_2.text: QuISP [40], the resource manager uses an internal set of rules to manage quantum memories. Figure 5

line_3.text: shows the structure of the resource manager. The network management module and application module

line_0.text: Quantum Sci. Technol. 6 (2021) 045027
X Wu et al
Figure 5. Resource management module.
use interface 1(cid:12) to retrieve the state of local resources and/or to install rules. These rules inform the

line_1.text: resource manager under what conditions it should allocate hardware resources to various entanglement

line_2.text: protocols. The hardware and entanglement management modules use interface 2(cid:12) to update the hardware

line_3.text: state and acquire/release resources. This ensures that the resource manager maintains an accurate count of

line_4.text: where resources are located as well as their internal state and ﬁdelity. Interface 3(cid:12) is used to communicate

line_5.text: with resource managers on other nodes. This communication is used to instantiate and terminate

line_6.text: entanglement protocol instances. When the resource manager creates (or terminates) a protocol instance, it

line_7.text: will send a message to the resource manager on the remote node(s) to create a (or terminate the)

line_8.text: corresponding entanglement protocol instance. For example, when performing entanglement generation,

line_9.text: one protocol instance must be created on each of the two adjacent router nodes to facilitate qubit

line_10.text: transmission timing. The two resource managers must then communicate to ensure the two protocol

line_11.text: instances are present and can communicate properly.

line_0.text: Within the resource manager, the memory manager traces the states of quantum memories. The
quantum memories can be in one of three states: raw, entangled, or occupied. The raw state means

line_1.text: that the memory is not entangled to other memories and is not in use. The entangled state means that

line_2.text: the memory is entangled to another memory or memories; entanglement information (such as the identity

line_3.text: of entangled memories and ﬁdelity) is also recorded by the memory manager. The occupied state means

line_4.text: that the memory has been allocated to an entanglement protocol instance, which prevents conﬂict in

line_5.text: memory allocation. The transition between states relates to the results of entanglement protocols.

line_0.text: Another component of the resource manager is the rule manager. The rule manager applies a rule set to
manage the hardware resources, determining where to allocate them to achieve the desired long-distance

line_1.text: entanglement. It installs new rules received from the network management module and uninstalls expired

line_2.text: rules. A rule consists of three parts: priority, condition, and action. Rules are sorted by priority from high to

line_3.text: low. The condition of a rule determines whether the state of a given memory ﬁts the rule. If the state ﬁts the

line_4.text: rule, the action of the rule will allocate the memory to an application or instantiated entanglement

line_5.text: protocol. As an example, consider a rule manager containing two rules and one memory. The two rules

line_6.text: have the same condition (e.g. the memory must be in the raw state) and different priorities and action (e.g.

line_7.text: the action of the rule with high priority allocates the memory to an instance of the entanglement generation

line_8.text: protocol; the action of the rule with low priority does nothing). The rule manager ﬁrst accesses the rule

line_9.text: with high priority. Then, the rule manager retrieves the state of the memory from the memory manager. If

line_10.text: the state of the memory satisﬁes the condition of rule (e.g. memory in raw state), the action of the rule is

line_11.text: executed (e.g. the rule creates an instance of the generation protocol). If the condition is not met, the rule

line_12.text: manager accesses the rule with lower priority to check whether the memory ﬁts the rule.

line_0.text: 4.4. Network management

line_1.text: The network management module enables applications to reserve network resources. This

line_2.text: reservation-based approach is inspired by the architecture proposed in a recent IETF quantum internet

line_3.text: working group draft [43]. Reservations are necessary to enable better coordination and to conserve the

line_4.text: extremely limited quantum memories in emerging quantum network architectures.

line_0.text: This module has two duties: reservation and routing. Reservation is responsible for fulﬁlling reserving
the local resources. Routing provides a path of entanglement distribution to satisfy the end-to-end

line_1.text: reservation. The reservation and routing protocols are designed to satisfy these duties. Figure 6 shows the

line_2.text: stack structure of the network manager.

line_0.text: Quantum Sci. Technol. 6 (2021) 045027
X Wu et al
Figure 6. Network management module.
To create entanglement between two nodes, the application makes a reservation request consisting of the
following six elements:
• Initiator: the initiator of the entanglement connection that is sending a reservation request (classical
message) toward the responder
• Responder: the other end of the connection setup process (and future entanglement connection),
where the message sent by the initiator terminates

line_1.text: • Fidelity: the target ﬁdelity of distributed entanglement

line_2.text: • Memory size: the memory provided by the initiator to distribute entanglement and requested of the

line_0.text: responder
• Start time: the time from when the resources need to be available for use by the application

line_1.text: • End time: the time when the resources can be released

line_2.text: Upon receiving a reservation request from an application 1(cid:12), the network manager pushes it to the

line_0.text: reservation instance which reserves appropriate resources (if available) and pushes the request to the

line_1.text: routing instance. The routing instance determines the next hop based on its forwarding table (details of this

line_2.text: table are given below) and pushes it to the network manager, which sends the message to the next hop. We

line_3.text: use the length of quantum channels to calculate the shortest path, which provides a static forwarding table

line_4.text: for the routing protocol on every node. This method can be updated to use a wide variety of routing

line_5.text: protocols including the ones used in classical networks, such as OSPF [45].

line_0.text: Upon receiving a message from a neighboring node 2(cid:12), the network manager pops it to the routing

line_1.text: instance, which then pops it to the reservation. If the reservation instance approves the request, it attaches

line_2.text: local information (e.g. the identity of the node) and pushes it back to the routing instance to send the

line_3.text: request to the next hop. If the message is rejected or it reaches the responder, the decision of the resource

line_4.text: manager will be sent back on the reverse path. If the reservation returns approved, all nodes prepare their

line_5.text: local rules to match the reservation. When the result arrives at the initiator, the reservation instance pops it

line_6.text: to the network manager, which then pops it to the application. A beneﬁt of this stack structure is that it is

line_7.text: easily expanded. For example, an authentication protocol could be placed at the top of the reservation

line_8.text: protocol to improve the security of a network while the rest of the protocols are inherited. For more details

line_9.text: about the design of the reservation protocol, see appendix D.

line_0.text: 4.5. Applications

line_1.text: The role of the application module is to consume entanglement. Quantum network applications are

line_2.text: heterogeneous (with varying requirements for throughput, ﬁdelity, etc), so in this work we create an

line_3.text: abstraction of a single application with random requests. These requests randomly choose a responder node

line_4.text: (with the initiator assumed to be the host node) as well as a target ﬁdelity for entanglement. Also assigned

line_5.text: randomly are the number of memories and the duration of the reservation. If a request fails, only the

line_6.text: responder and ﬁdelity are kept; the other parameters are randomly reassigned, and the updated request is

line_7.text: sent after waiting for 1 s. We record the results of simulations using this application description in section 5.

line_8.text: The SeQUeNCe simulator also provides a reference implementation of quantum key distribution, but

line_9.text: studying behavior of speciﬁc applications is beyond the scope of this work.

line_0.text: 5. Three simulation use cases
This section highlights three representative examples of simulations performed with SeQUeNCe. The intent

line_1.text: of these use cases is not to focus on extensive quantum network performance evaluations, which is beyond

line_2.text: the scope of this paper’s goal to introduce the uses of a modular open-source quantum network simulator.

line_3.text: We make the examples presented here, as well as many others, part of the open-source release of SeQUeNCe

line_4.text: to help the research community start using the tool. In addition, this paper makes several interesting

line_5.text: observations that include quantifying the impact of quantum memory parameters, the adverse effect of

line_6.text: classical channel delays on quantum channel throughput, and the impact of memory distribution policy on

line_7.text: memory utilization and overall network performance. The source code and results of all simulations are

line_8.text: available on GitHub [56].

line_0.text: 5.1. Simulation setup

line_1.text: Our use cases share the following simulation setup. The topology is modeled after the Chicago

line_2.text: metropolitan quantum network, which consists of nine nodes located at ﬁve sites as depicted in ﬁgure 7.

line_3.text: The simulated topology augments the actual topology by adding three quantum links to provide richer

line_4.text: connectivity. In addition, a BSM node required by the generation protocol (see section 4.2.1) is placed in

line_5.text: the middle of every optical link to enable BSM operations.

line_0.text: The quantum channel delay is modeled as the propagation delay on the optical ﬁber (see section 4.1.1).

line_1.text: The classical channel delay was obtained by performing round-trip time (RTT) measurements between the

line_2.text: ﬁve sites, as shown in table 1. The one-way classical channel delay was calculated by halving and averaging

line_3.text: the two-directional RTTs between sites, and one-way delays within a site were set to 0.25 ms. Each of the

line_4.text: nine nodes in our network is equipped with quantum memories and supports all protocols described in

line_5.text: section 4. Nodes are therefore able to assume the role of a quantum router. The default hardware

line_6.text: parameters in our setup are shown in table 2. These values represent properties of state-of-the-art hardware

line_7.text: components. Each router contains 50 memories by default. While this memory capacity is beyond the scope

line_8.text: of near-term physical realizations, this choice provides insights into how networks with non-trivial

line_0.text: In the course of simulations, applications running on all nodes request quantum network resources

line_1.text: repeatedly for 1000 s of simulation time, and performance metrics such as entanglement throughput and

line_2.text: memory utilization are recorded. The application requests are random, choosing a random responder,

line_3.text: random target entanglement ﬁdelity between 0.8 and 1, duration of the reservation between 10 and 20 s,

line_4.text: and a start time at 1 to 2 s after the present time. These requests reserve a number of memories between 10

line_5.text: and half of the available memory capacity in the initiator node. Once the request is approved, entanglement

line_6.text: distribution rules are installed. These rules ﬁrst ensure that entanglement is generated between adjacent

line_7.text: nodes. Once the entanglement is generated, its ﬁdelity is traced by formula (3) and formula (5).

line_0.text: 5.2. Comparison of quantum memory parameters

line_1.text: The attributes of quantum memories greatly affect network performance. As equation (1) shows, ﬁdelity of

line_2.text: entanglement increases with increasing atom-cavity cooperativity of the quantum memory. Accordingly, we

line_3.text: evaluated the network performance for different combinations of cooperativities and efﬁciencies. We

line_4.text: assumed that the memory frequency is 2 KHz and the target ﬁdelity is between 0.8 and 1.

line_0.text: Experimental cooperativity C for Er emitters coupled to an optical cavity is in the range of 50 to 500
[23, 52]. Memory efﬁciencies are not yet perfect and can vary signiﬁcantly depending on the photonic

line_1.text: coupling scheme adopted [31, 52, 76]. Therefore, we simulated quantum memories with cooperativity

line_2.text: C = {50, 100, 500} and efﬁciency ηm = {0.01, 0.10, 0.50, 0.75}. Figure 8 shows the average throughput per

line_3.text: ﬂow for each of the simulated values of cooperativity C and efﬁciency ηm. We observe the following. First,

line_4.text: performance generally improves with increasing efﬁciency. This is because a memory with the same

line_5.text: cooperativity will generate entanglement with higher probability, reducing the number of entanglement

line_6.text: generation protocol failures. Second, the improvement of cooperativity does not provide as much increase

line_7.text: in throughput as the improvement of efﬁciency because for the range of simulated cooperativity the ﬁdelity

line_8.text: is already high (>0.9).

line_0.text: This use case illustrates how to use SeQUeNCe to explore the effect of hardware parameters. This

line_1.text: particular example is valuable for experimentalists building network prototypes because it identiﬁes the

line_2.text: threshold hardware metrics to achieve the desired network performance.

line_0.text: 5.3. Impact of classical channel delay

line_1.text: Quantum routers rely on classical messages to determine the state of quantum memories, even if

line_2.text: manipulating quantum states does not inherently require classical messages. The delay of classical channels

line_3.text: thus affects the latency of quantum network protocols. Next, we compare the quantum network

line_4.text: performance in two scenarios: (1) using the measured RTT delays in the Chicago topology and (2) using

line_5.text: projected delays of dedicated classical channels that try to avoid unnecessary queuing and processing delays.

line_6.text: These projected delays were calculated by adding propagation delay (speed of light in the ﬁber for the given

line_7.text: distance), a transmission delay of 8 μs, and a processing delay of 4 μs. The transmission delay corresponds

line_0.text: Quantum Sci. Technol. 6 (2021) 045027
X Wu et al
Figure 8. Average per ﬂow throughput for various combinations of memory efﬁciency and atom-cavity cooperativity.
Figure 9. Average per ﬂow network throughput achieved for different quantum memory frequencies.
to sending a 1000 byte control packet over a 1 Gbps link, and the processing delay represents the time to

line_1.text: process the packet [58]. We assume each packet has the highest priority, and we ignore queuing delays.

line_2.text: Under these assumptions, the delay for a typical classical channel in our setup reduces from milliseconds to

line_3.text: microseconds.

line_0.text: To evaluate the effect of this delay reduction, we analyze the performance of the network by recording

line_1.text: the network ﬂow throughputs for different memory frequencies. We set the memory efﬁciency to ηm = 0.75

line_2.text: and the cooperativity to C = 500, a combination that achieves the best performance (see section 5.2). Our

line_3.text: simulation results are shown in ﬁgure 9. We observe that the scenario with low classical channel delay gains

line_4.text: more beneﬁt at higher memory frequencies. For example, the average throughput improves by more than a

line_5.text: factor of 10 for 20 kHz memories. Another interesting observation is that the increase of frequency from

line_6.text: 2 kHz to 20 kHz does not signiﬁcantly improve the performance of networks with long classical channel

line_7.text: delays. The longer delay imposes a limit on the speed at which states can be manipulated by control

line_8.text: protocols, rendering the throughput gain from higher memory frequencies insigniﬁcant. Thus, we conclude

line_9.text: that quantum networks should use low-latency classical control messages to utilize quantum hardware

line_0.text: 6. Related work
Besides SeQUeNCe, there are two other quantum network simulators with ambition to comprehensively

line_1.text: model the behavior of full-stack quantum networks. QuISP [39, 40] has been introduced as an open source

line_2.text: package in mid-2020, and NetSquid [17, 20] recently became available upon request. QuISP [39, 40]

line_3.text: supports various entanglement puriﬁcation protocols, link tomography, and entanglement swapping.

line_4.text: QuISP also focuses on scalability, with a stated goal of simulating a full quantum internet of up to 100

line_5.text: networks with up to 100 nodes each. One published result [40] focuses on modeling a variety of error

line_6.text: sources but restricts the studied scenarios to point-to-point communication with and without repeater

line_7.text: nodes over distances of up to 50 km. According to the NetSquid [70] project website, Netsquid focuses on

line_8.text: simulation using NV caters in diamond and ensemble memories, whereas SeQUeNCe focuses on single

line_9.text: rare-earth ion memories. Both simulators offer the ﬂexibility to study other technologies as well. In

line_10.text: addition, work published by the NetSquid team [20] developed and analyzed physical and link layer

line_11.text: protocols, and evaluations included simulations of point-to-point communication between two nodes in

line_12.text: the lab (2 m) and two cities (25 km).

line_0.text: Quantum network simulators are quickly evolving and features are often added on a daily basis, making
comparisons quickly obsolete. The biggest differences can be found in architectural assumptions. For

line_1.text: example, QuISP uses RuleSets that are distributed to nodes along a path at connection setup time. The

line_2.text: NetSquid team proposed a ﬁve-layer quantum network stack with physical, link, network, transmission, and

line_3.text: application layers [20], but the NetSquid simulator itself follows a modularized framework to allow

line_4.text: modeling a variety of architectures. SeQUeNCe also follows a modularized design and uses cross-module

line_5.text: communication to allow maximum simulation ﬂexibility.

line_0.text: Recently introduced, QuNetSim [22] is a simulator capable of smaller-scale simulations of 5 to 10 nodes
that also uses a network layering framework inspired by the OSI model. However, the simulator focuses

line_1.text: only on the upper layers, leaving the physical layer unspeciﬁed. QuNetSim allows simulating entanglement

line_2.text: swapping but the current release does not support entanglement puriﬁcation. Another simulator,

line_3.text: SQUANCH [4], is notable for its agent-based modeling, allowing natural parallelization by running each

line_4.text: agent on its own process. Because the simulator does not attempt to model interactions of protocols or

line_5.text: details at the physical layer, the simulator is suitable for demonstrations of concepts such as teleportation

line_6.text: [7] or superdense coding [9]. SimulaQron [21] aims to simulate quantum networks with the goal to

line_0.text: Quantum Sci. Technol. 6 (2021) 045027
X Wu et al
facilitate the development of network applications, but does not model time-dependent noise. It uses the

line_1.text: classical–quantum combiner interface [54] with sockets that mimic information transmission over

line_2.text: simulated quantum channels.

line_0.text: Many additional simulation tools exist that can be used to perform numerical studies of individual

line_1.text: quantum network algorithms and protocols [16, 32, 42, 48, 50]. Many additional tools are listed on the

line_2.text: website of the Quantum Open Source Foundation [30].

line_0.text: 7. Conclusion
In this paper we introduced SeQUeNCe, a customizable discrete-event quantum network simulator. We

line_1.text: introduced a modularized design for the simulator that closely matches an abstracted quantum network

line_2.text: architecture, and we implemented a high-performance simulation kernel that allows simulating

line_3.text: transmission and tracking of photon pulses and control messages with picosecond accuracy. We also

line_4.text: implemented a comprehensive suite of quantum network protocols, including translation of the algorithmic

line_5.text: descriptions into fully functional protocol state machines.

line_0.text: Our planned next steps include support for additional protocols to allow more comprehensive
performance evaluations, as well as parallelization of the tool for use on multinode, multicore

line_1.text: supercomputers. By releasing SeQUeNCe as open source software, we aim to generate community interest

line_2.text: in using and extending the simulator, as well as allow comparisons of experimental and simulation results

line_3.text: obtained by other teams.

line_0.text: Appendix
Here we describe several quantum network protocols implemented in SeQUeNCe. Practical usability of

line_1.text: these protocols requires not only their correct operation, but also ability to tolerate arbitrary failures or

line_2.text: message delays that may occur in distributed network environments. For this reason protocols must be

line_3.text: described as state machines with well-deﬁned state transitions, often consisting of dozens of states.

line_4.text: Simpliﬁed versions of these state machines are shown in this appendix.

line_0.text: The SeQUeNCe implementation of the Barrett–Kok protocol is instantiated on each quantum node and
paired by the resource management module. The state machines of the protocol instances at the quantum

line_1.text: nodes and at the BSM are shown in ﬁgure A1. We now describe the classical message exchange between a

line_2.text: pair of nodes using the Barrett–Kok protocol in SeQUeNCe. A designated member of the pair will start

line_3.text: communication with an NEGOTIATE message (shown as ‘negotiate parameters’ in ﬁgure A1). The protocol

line_4.text: instance on the other node responds with an offer, and the Barrett–Kok protocol can begin. The

line_5.text: NEGOTIATE message and its response ensure that the two memories emit photons simultaneously. The

line_6.text: two quantum nodes then schedule the excite operations on their respective memories and wait for a

line_7.text: measurement result via the MR (measurement result) message from the BSM node. If an improper result is

line_8.text: received, the protocol ends with a failure, and each instance reports its failure to its respective resource

line_9.text: manager. Otherwise, the protocol instance applies an X-gate and proceeds to round 2, repeating the process

line_10.text: of round 1. If both rounds are completed successfully, the two memories are conﬁrmed to be entangled, an

line_11.text: entanglement result is returned to the resource manager. Regardless of whether the protocol succeeds or

line_12.text: fails, the protocol instance destroys itself and releases the quantum memories back to the resource manager.

line_13.text: The protocol instance at the node executing the BSM is not created or destroyed by a top-level resource

line_14.text: manager; it is always present. It waits in an idle start state for any photon detection event and then notiﬁes

line_15.text: adjacent quantum nodes of the entanglement result with an MR message. Note that the lifetime of

line_16.text: entanglement starts at the ﬁrst excite operation.

line_0.text: The instances of the modeled BBPSSW protocol are created and paired by their respective resource

line_1.text: managers. When two of these instances are initialized properly, they start the procedure of puriﬁcation.

line_2.text: Figure B1 shows the state diagram for the BBPSSW protocol model. A quantum circuit with a CNOT gate

line_3.text: and Z-basis measurement is applied to the two quantum memories. The measurement causes the target pair

line_4.text: (A2, B2) to lose its entanglement. After running the circuit, the protocol holds the result of local

line_5.text: measurement and waits for the measurement result from the remote protocol instance. The same

line_6.text: measurement results for both protocols indicate the success of the puriﬁcation procedure. The unmeasured

line_7.text: memory (A1, B1) keeps its entanglement state and the ﬁdelity of entanglement is improved. If the

line_8.text: measurement results differ, the puriﬁcation attempt fails. The unmeasured memory loses its entanglement.

line_0.text: Appendix C. Entanglement swapping
Figure C1 shows the state machines for the entanglement swapping protocol at both end and intermediate

line_1.text: nodes. The intermediate node determines if the swapping operation succeeds using the probability of

line_2.text: success. If the swapping succeeds, the measurement results are sent to the paired end nodes. Then, the

line_3.text: intermediate node ﬁnishes its work and releases resources. The end nodes start and wait for the message

line_4.text: from the intermediate node. If the message shows the swapping operation succeeded, the protocol instance

line_5.text: updates the identity of the entangled memory and ﬁdelity. Additionally, the protocol applies the correct

line_6.text: quantum circuit to the memory. If the swapping operation failed, the entanglement state is removed. The

line_7.text: updated memory is then released to the resource manager.

line_0.text: Appendix D. Reservation protocol
Figure D1 shows the state machine of the reservation protocol. A protocol instance starts upon arrival of a

line_1.text: request message. The protocol instance checks whether sufﬁcient local memory is available from the start

line_2.text: time to the end time of the request. If sufﬁcient memory is available, the instance will attach its local

line_3.text: information and forward the message to the next hop in the path until the message arrives at the responder.

line_4.text: Every quantum router in the path holds the quantum memory resources until it receives an APPROVE

line_5.text: message. When the request is approved by the responder, this APPROVE message is created and sent back to

line_6.text: conﬁrm the success of reservation. Once a protocol instance conﬁrms reservation with an APPROVE

line_7.text: message, the corresponding local rules are created and scheduled. If the protocol instance of any node on

line_8.text: the path (responder included) rejects the request, an REJECT message is sent back to the previous hop

line_0.text: Quantum Sci. Technol. 6 (2021) 045027
X Wu et al
Figure C1. State machine of entanglement swapping.
Figure D1. State machine of reservation protocol.
until it arrives at the initiator. All reservations from the request are canceled. When the protocol instance on

line_1.text: the initiator receives the result of the request, it sends the result to the application module.

line_0.text: A reservation protocol instance creates three rules to provide service. The ﬁrst rule deﬁnes the
conditions and actions for entanglement generation. If the state of reserved memory is raw, the memory is

line_1.text: allocated to an instance of the generation protocol. The second rule deﬁnes conditions and actions for

line_2.text: entanglement puriﬁcation. If two reserved memories have same ﬁdelity of entanglement and the current

line_3.text: ﬁdelity is lower than the target ﬁdelity, the two memories are allocated to an instance of the puriﬁcation

line_4.text: protocol. The third rule deﬁnes conditions and actions for entanglement swapping. If the two reserved

line_5.text: memories are entangled with memories on speciﬁc nodes and the ﬁdelity of entanglement is larger than the

line_6.text: target ﬁdelity, the two memories are allocated to an instance of the entanglement swapping protocol.
